thread.title: Christmas market cruises coming to Mississippi River
thread.title_full: Christmas market cruises coming to Mississippi River

author: Gene Sloan , USA TODAY
title: Christmas market cruises coming to Mississippi River
text:
The Memphis-based American Queen Steamboat Company re-introduced the 436-passenger American Queen on the Mississippi River in April 2012. The vessel hasn't operated since the demise of the Majestic America Line in late 2008. Courtesy Great American Steamboat Company Fullscreen American Queen Steamboat is trying to revive what was once a robust overnight cruise business on the Mississippi and its tributaries -- a business that collapsed over the past decade with the back-to-back shutdowns of the Delta Queen Steamboat Company in 2001 and the Majestic America Line in 2008.The American Queen sailed for both lines in an on-again-off-again career on America's waterways that has seen it laid up as much as it has been in operation. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Built in 1995 at a cost of $60 million, the 418-foot-long American Queen is an authentic steamboat propelled by the large red paddle wheel on its back. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Billed as the grandest, most opulent riverboat ever built, the American Queen boasts warm, antebellum decor and showboat-style entertainment. Here, the Grand Saloon, the vessel's main showroom. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Inspired by the greatest steamboats of the 19th century, the American Queen's two-level Grand Saloon offers nightly entertainment that ranges from Broadway musicals to Dixieland Jazz to showboat-style cabaret. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The second level of the Grand Saloon has private boxes that are reserved for passengers staying in the American Queen's biggest suites. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The view from one of the Grand Saloon's private boxes. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Public areas on the American Queen have a Victorian flair, as seen here in the ship's main deck Lounge. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the Lounge, which leads into the vessel's J.M. White Dining Room. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The J.M. White Dining Room accommodates the ship's 436 passengers for dinner in two seatings. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The ceiling of the American Queen's J.M. White Dining Room soars two stories in places and has large windows that look out to the rivers on which the American Queen sails. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The view from the Purser's Lobby looking down the grand staircase to the Lounge. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Purser's Lobby is home to a Purser's Station and a shore excursion desk. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Adorned with rich paneling, crystal chandeliers and period furniture, the Mark Twain Gallery serves as a central gathering point on the American Queen. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Victorian furniture including sofas, plush armchairs and side tables fill the Mark Twain Gallery. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Cases along the walls of the Mark Twain Gallery hold riverboat memorabilia and other historic objects. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A wide view of the Mark Twain Gallery. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A highlight of the Mark Twain Gallery is a model of the 1920s-era Delta Queen, which sailed alongside the American Queen until 2008. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Passengers in the Mark Twain Gallery often are treated to live piano music played on this upright piano. Gene Sloan Fullscreen One of the few non-period objects in the Mark Twain Gallery is this self-serve coffee machine. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The American Queen also offers a number of smaller lounges, including the Gentleman's Card Room on the vessel's second deck. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located across from the Gentleman's Card Room is the Ladies Parlor. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located at the front of the ship is the Front Porch of America, a sitting area from where passengers can view the great expanse of the rivers on which the American Queen travels. Here, the inside portion of the Front Porch. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Front Porch of America's inside area offers coffee and tea around the clock. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The outside portion of the Front Porch of America features rocking chairs and swings. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located one deck above the Front Porch of America at the front of the ship is the Chart Room, which features nautical charts and also serves as the vessel's library. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located on one of the top decks at the back of the American Queen is the River Grill, an outdoor bar and food area. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The American Queen features a small pool area, a rarity on river vessels. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up of the American Queen's pool, which is located on the Sun Deck, the highest of the vessel's six decks. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Sun Deck also features seating areas from where passengers can view passing attractions. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The American Queen has 233 cabins spread over four decks, and many of the cabins have entrances opening onto promenades encircling the vessel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Each of the American Queen's cabins is given an individual name. Here, the Tennessee room, billed as a Deluxe Outside Stateroom with Veranda. Gene Sloan Fullscreen As with all the cabins on the American Queen, the Tennessee room features period Victorian furnishings mixed with modern amenities such as a flat-screen. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like many of the cabins on the American Queen, the Tennessee room's bed faces large double doors that open onto a promenade encircling the vessel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The closet area of the Tennessee room is typical of what is found in the Deluxe Outside Stateroom with Veranda category of cabins Gene Sloan Fullscreen Bathrooms in the Deluxe Outside Stateroom with Veranda category boast a period look. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Bathrooms in the Deluxe Outside Stateroom with Veranda category offer a combination bathtub and shower. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Instead of the built-in desks and storage areas found on many modern river ships, most of the American Queen's cabins feature free-standing furniture. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A view of another Deluxe Outside Statemroom with Veranda, the California room. Cabin decor varies from room to room. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The California room's bathroom is designed for passengers with disabilities. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The shower area of the California's bathroom, which is designed for passengers with disabilities. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The interior of the California room's armoire. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Larger than the Deluxe Outside Staterooms are the American Queen's 16 Superior Outside Staterooms with Verandas. Here, the Betsy Blake room (cabin 522). Gene Sloan Fullscreen American Queen cabins feature old-fashioned keys instead of more modern electronic keycards. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The American Queen also features 20 suites located on one of the vessel's highest decks. Here, the Gordon C. Greene Suite (cabin 518), named after the patriarch of the family that founded the Delta Queen Steamboat Company. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Another suite on the vessel, the Hernando de Soto (cabin 520). Gene Sloan Fullscreen In addition to elevators, a Victorian-style stairway connects the American Queen's passenger decks. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Located at the back of the American Queen, over the engine room, is the Engine Room Bar. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Piano music is a staple of the Engine Room Bar, which has portholes looking out over the American Queen's paddle wheel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The elegant wooden bar at the center of the Engine Room Bar. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The Engine Room Bar also offers two outdoor seating areas with views of the American Queen's paddle wheel. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The view of the American Queen's paddle wheel from one of the Engine Room Bar's two outdoor seating areas. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A traditional steam-powered calliope located on the back of the American Queen is often played by crew members on board, offering a historical touch as the vessel is underway. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The American Queen is U.S.-flagged and carries a U.S. crew, with many of the ship's workers coming from the Memphis area. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A view of one of the two large smokestacks at the front of the American Queen, which can be temporarily lowered so the vessel can fit under bridges. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like steamboats of old, the front of the American Queen features walkways that are designed for use during stops where a dock is not available. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A grand stairway leads up to the main entrance at the front of the American Queen. Gene Sloan Fullscreen A close-up view of the doorway at the front of the American Queen. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Among the historical items adorning the walls of the American Queen's interior are flyers from steamboat races that took place decades ago. Gene Sloan Fullscreen The vessel's A.Q. Emporium store sells American Queen memorabilia and clothing. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Books about the history of steamboats and America's waterways are available in the A.Q. Emporium store. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Elvis Presley items for sale at the A.Q. Emporium. The American Queen Steamboat Company has partnered with Presley Enterprises to host an Elvis cruise. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Spa treatments are offered on the American Queen for an extra charge. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Priscilla Presley, former wife of Elvis Presley, re-christened the American Queen on April 27, 2012 in a ceremony along the Memphis waterfront. Gene Sloan Fullscreen An American Queen life buoy. Gene Sloan Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide The American Queen steamboat will be the hub for a bourbon-themed vacation in July. (Photo: American Queen Steamboat Co.)
Tags Mississippi River American Queen American Queen Steamboat Company 203 CONNECT 72 TWEET 2 LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Christmas market cruises, long popular on Europe's rivers, are coming to the USA.
The American Queen Steamboat Company on Friday will announce that its holiday sailings on the Mississippi River will include stops at new Christmas markets that feature music as well as vendors selling seasonal and locally produced crafts and goods.
American Queen Steamboat president and COO Ted Sykes tells USA TODAY the company has worked with local tourist offices and port officials in such towns as Greenville, Miss., to arrange the Christmas markets.
Passengers on the sailings, on the 436-passenger American Queen , also will experience such special holiday entertainment as strolling carolers in St. Francisville, La., and departure serenades from the levees of Vicksburg and Natchez, Miss.
The offerings expand on existing holiday traditions along the Mississippi such as bonfires to welcome the arrival of Papa Noel, Sykes says.
USA TODAY
Love bourbon? This cruise is for you
"Those traditions and festivities always have been there. We're just amping it up for our guests," he says, adding that "the towns really have embraced" the idea of Christmas markets.
The sailings also will feature an on-board group of performers called the Steamboat Syncopators who will sing holiday songs throughout the journey.
The American Queen sails week-long holiday voyages between Memphis, Tenn. and New Orleans, La. from around Thanksgiving through New Year's week.
American Queen Steamboat has scheduled six holiday sailings on the Mississippi this year, departing on Nov. 21 and 28; and Dec. 5, 12, 19 and 26. Fares start at $2,699 per person, based on double occupancy, including a one-night, pre-voyage hotel stay; shore tours in all ports; and complimentary wine and beer with dinner.
For a deck-by-deck tour of the American Queen, click through the carousel at the top of this story.
